comments.commentBody:
'By contrast, if it breaks with the euro its goods and services would suddenly become far more competitive in the world economy as their price would fall due to a lower valued currency.'

And I also thought this was the funniest part of his post. Doesn't he know that the Euro always will be Greeces currency - even if the country 'officially' would go back on some Monoploy money?

Patience? You've got to living in a fantasy world. This will wind up being a fools mission on our part. We were duped and out-played from the moment we agreed to the talks. An we will fall for another request for an extension.
What part of, "Death to America" do you consider free of war drums?
Nope. We don't need to wait, because even the best deal will still be bad.
Can we have the patience to wait for the Tuesday deadline to pass before beating the war drums?

The US has not kept its Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty obligations either.  Regarding the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty: ""There exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control." per the International Court of Justice.
So what is your point?  The issue is not the commentators here, but Iran's decision...or maybe they were never going along with it in the first place?

Yeah, I mean, what reason do we have to be skeptical of the governments involved? They've never steered us wrong before.

One thing's for sure, you're certainly not wrong about the overabundance of fools.

There would be no need for negotiations if Iran truely didn't want a nuke.  The only reason they are at the table is because of the sanctions. Once those are lifted they will be home free to make a nuke on the sly. That's reality. North Korea is proof of that scenario.

The knee jerk reactions (or maybe just the reactions of jerks) are as laughable as they are ill-considered.  The naysayers are keen to say "I told you so" and strain to make their "prophecies" self-fulfilling.  Only a fool would campaign for the failure of these talks, but it seems we have no shortage of those, unfortunately.  How about we just wait until the talks have concluded and the details of an agreement - if one even emerges - are disclosed?

@EGD: "and, yes, that would mean war with the mullahs, unfortunately."  And whose sons and daughters would be fighting that war?  Yours?   Be advised that Iran's "leadership cult" is no more messianic than that of Israel.  The policies of both governments are very much dependent upon messianic prophecy.  Which also happens to be the case for American evangelicals whose ardent support for Israel is tied to the notion that the second coming of Jesus is predicated by Jewish control of the Holy Land.  As for "Iran killing Americans since 1979"- you're probably referring to acts committed by terrorist organizations they support. Only there's no conclusive evidence that Tehran ordered any of those attacks. most of which were conducted by Sunni organizations that despise the "Persians" even more than they do us.
We cannot point fingers-of-blame at either party, since it takes two people for such activity.

It's time to stop blaming Ms. Lewinsky for President Clinton's indiscretions.  On the other hand, it's also time to stop talking and writing about her.  She didn't deserve her fifteen minutes of infamy and she similarly does not merit fifteen minutes of fame.

We're living in a time when John Bolton (remember him? U.S. ambassador to the UN... yes, really..) advocates that we should bomb Iran and is applauded by his Conservative supporters and disciples, Netanyahu speaks in the U.S. against our President at the request of Congress (kind of like Obama going to Israel uninvited and speaking to Arabs about what to do about Netanyahu), and the NYTs, that supported war in Iraq in 2003 thinks, now, 13 years later, when we've destroyed the region, that Obama is "escalating" "dangerously."

Rationality is out the window, Paul, so, no all the attention given to Latvia looks, oddly enough, not odd at all.
.
Make that "predicated ON Jewish control, etc.."  My bad.

Starbucks just ran a campaign to position their brand as progressive without doing anything on the ground to effect change.  They got a lot of publicity because it got people upset.  I suspect that Microsoft--in doing something that puts real money on the table to add value to society--will receive far less press than Starbucks did for printing a slogan on a coffee cup.
Details please?
Lawmakers aren't the one who handle the technical aspects of writing and publishing. This is a logistics process for their staff.
Brackets are great!
Link is incorrect. This is the right one: http://www.thekitchn.com/technique-how-to-use-tamarind-90339

Depending on your spice tolerance, I would suggest adding a adding either chopped fresh thai bird chili peppers or whole dried red chilis to the step when you stir fry the garlic and ginger. The last time I made this I added a particularly spicy Serrano chili to that step and it added a mild heat to the whole thing that was almost magical.
If you change your link to show "thekitchn" instead of 'thekitchen" it will work!

1) Recipe as presented is good but too mild to my tastes, even with addition of 1/4 tsp of red pepper flakes to the recipe. I preferred it with the addition of some additional Tsang Szechuan Spicey stir fry sauce( hot pepper, onion, ginger and garlic) which I added to taste at the table. (2) Tamarind paste a bit hard to find and use, but per my reading very important to final product. Suggest reading at www.thekitchen.com/technique-how-to-use-tamarind for this part of recipe.

and Elke

I CAME to it STARKLY. Unlike Jane EYRE I am ensnared by a net :i.e. the Internet.
I can see that scenario playing out at your avatar's home.  "I can't, honey, it's Lent."  Reply: "Who did you lend it to and when do you get it back?"

I know that it isn't healthy, but... this is fantastic. I would recommend watching the salt all around. I used the recommended salt in the dough, but used unsalted mozzarella, sauce (made of canned tomatoes, olive oil and salt) prosciutto de parma and salted the first pizza (which was a mistake). Even cutting salting the remaining pizzas, it was still a bit on the salty side for me. Everyone else enjoyed it though!
At the top of my list for an excellent dish after a hard day when I'm hungry but have no patience for extended cooking!

I think the point is that there are differing views on that matter. Not everyone does think anonymous donation is wrong; some parents and children prefer it. Countries differ on whether anonymity is required, forbidden or a matter of choice. It sounds as though Israel requires anonymity. I think it's probably better for the child psychologically to be told at an early age and have the option of later meeting the donor as an adult, but that isn't an option in many cases. Luckily, companies like 23andme should make it pretty easy for these kids to learn about their genetics or track down genetic relatives someday. I would guess many will not be interested.  Even in my family, there's a wide variation in interest in family history. I do think the vehemence of some of the responses to Amy Klein have been off putting. This up is her child and she will undoubtedly be able to answer his questions when the time comes.

Although technology would certainly help wean us off fossil fuels, I don't believe that new technology is even necessary to achieve the goal.

Community planning that increases the willingness of people to walk and ride bikes would be an easy start, and would require little investment.

Today's mass-produced solar panels running at 23% efficiency simply need to be deployed. There's no technological reason that San Diego, for example, isn't 100% solar at peak demand hours (daytime).

I like your ideas and appreciate your comment. Just wanted to add my perspective.
We're very much looking forward to see some heroes of our youth again: http://www.diedenker.org/inhalte/akte-x-revival/

Soon abandon it? I didn't even watch this episode! I'll binge-watch to fast-forward to Marissa and Kalinda scenes someday. Saw both of them in clips currently available on cbs.com.

Which version of "Blade Runner"? I think they are up to 6. It's a film w/wonderful aspects but too much Sean Young for my taste. Yet I've watched it dozens of times!

Highly recommended:

1. http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/the-americans-nudity-keri-ru...

2. A one-minute video of Lois Smith screen-testing w/James Dean 60 years ago. Sorry I don't have a link, but check Youtube or elsewhere under "East of Eden". Ms. Smith was way prettier than Keri Russell was at a comparable age. But Ms. Russell has nothing to be embarrassed about in the looks department; and may even eventually match Ms. Smith talent-wise.

Either way, three words for Emmy nominators: For. Your. Consideration.

A small and hopeful sign that not all is over in Hong Kong.

I am really sick of the brainwashing that passes for mainland Chinese news: namely, claims that 'Western factions' aka the United States are responsible for the Umbrella movement in Hong Kong. Is it really so incomprehensible that normal, self-respecting citizens would want to select their own leader via some form of democracy, and that this desire is inherent in any individual who knows better, not just an American one?
